questions.text:
A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of abdominal pain and nausea over the past 2 weeks and a 1-month history of pain in his knees and hips. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Physical examination shows decreased muscle strength. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.0 mg/dL


Serum



Creatinine
1.5 mg/dL


Calcium
12.2 mg/dL


Parathyroid hormone
5 pg/mL


Parathyroid hormone-related peptide
elevated


Urine



Blood
2+


Ultrasonography of his abdomen shows a 6-cm mass in his right kidney. Nephrectomy is performed. A photograph of the resected specimen is shown. The patient's tumor most likely originated from which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has renal cell carcinoma, which does not arise from the distal convoluted tubules.

B) CORRECT:

The epithelial cells of the proximal convoluted tubules are the most common site for the origin of renal cell carcinoma (RCC), which often presents with anemia, hematuria, and elevated creatinine. The tumor is typically well-circumscribed and has a golden-yellow color due to its high lipid content. Clear cell carcinoma is the most common type of RCC. In clear cell carcinoma, the cells appear clear on microscopy because the lipid and glycogen content is removed during the formalin-based fixation process.

RCC can produce PTH-related peptide (PTHrP), which mimics the effects of PTH and causes hypercalcemia. The symptoms of hypercalcemia include abdominal pain and decreased muscle strength. High calcium levels also suppress PTH production from the parathyroid glands. Other hormones that can be produced by RCC include ACTH, erythropoietin, and renin.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (H&E stain, 350x magnification)

The renal tubules (black circles) can be seen within the renal parenchyma on the left. The tumor cells have spread beyond the renal capsule (faded area) and have an enlarged cytoplasm that appears clear due to high lipid and glycogen content.

This is the typical histological appearance of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has renal cell carcinoma, which does not arise from the glomerulus.

D) INCORRECT:

Transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) can occasionally arise from the renal pelvis and cause hematuria as well as features of urinary tract obstruction (e.g., abdominal pain, increased creatinine). However, TCC would appear as an infiltrative polypoid mass that fills up the pelvicalyceal system. The nephrectomy specimen from this patient shows a well-circumscribed tumor that arises primarily in the renal parenchyma. Moreover, TCC is not associated with paraneoplastic hormone production, as seen here.
Image Description:

Nephrectomy specimen (sagittal section)

A large white tumor can be seen in the space previously occupied by the renal pelvis and the ureteral stump.

This is the typical macroscopic appearance of urothelial carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal oncocytomas and chromophobic renal cell carcinomas (RCC) arise from the cells of the collecting tubules and present similarly with abdominal pain and hematuria. In addition, both of these tumors would be well-circumscribed and localized to the renal parenchyma, as seen in this image below. However, an oncocytoma typically has a central scar, which is not present in the photograph of the resected specimen (above), and it would not be associated with paraneoplastic hormone production. This patient has RCC, however, the chromophobic form of RCC is rare and most RCCs arise from a different structure.
Image Description:

Gross pathology specimen of a kidney (sagittal section)

A well-circumscribed, mahogany-brown tumor (green overlay) with a central scar (hatched green overlay) is visible.

These findings are characteristic of a renal oncocytoma.
questions.hint: This patient's history, ultrasound results, and surgical specimen indicate renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The structure from which RCC most likely originated from is also affected by Fanconi syndrome.

questions.text:
An obese 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of 3 episodes of red urine over the past week. During the past month, he has also had recurrent headaches and intermittent blurry vision. He has benign prostatic hyperplasia. He works as an attendant at a gas station. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years. He does not drink alcohol. Current medications include tamsulosin. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 152/95 mm Hg. Examination shows a flushed face. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Digital rectal examination shows an enlarged prostate with no nodules. Urinalysis shows:


Blood
3+


Glucose
negative


Protein
negative


WBCs
1–2/hpf


RBCs
40–45/hpf


RBC casts
none


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nephrolithiasis may present with hematuria, as described here. Small kidney stones may also be asymptomatic. However, the diagnosis is unlikely in a patient with gross hematuria but no symptoms of renal colic (e.g., severe unilateral and colicky flank pain). Nephrolithiasis would also not explain the patient's paraneoplastic EPO production.

B) INCORRECT:

Episodic gross hematuria may be seen in patients with IgA nephropathy. This condition commonly occurs in children and young adults with an upper respiratory infection or gastroenteritis, but this older patient did not report or show any signs of recent infection. Moreover, urinalysis in IgA nephropathy usually shows red blood cell casts (due to glomerular involvement), making the diagnosis even less likely in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Transitional cell cancer most frequently presents with painless gross hematuria, as seen in this patient. Moreover, this patient does have some of the associated risk factors (e.g., smoking and possible occupational exposure to diesel exhaust). However, he has symptoms of paraneoplastic EPO production (headache, facial plethora, blurry vision), which is generally not associated with transitional cell carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Pyelonephritis is a possible cause of hematuria. In this patient, the presence of residual urine secondary to benign prostatic enlargement could have increased the risk of ascending urinary tract infection and pyelonephritis. However, in addition to the hematuria seen in this patient, urinalysis would typically show pyuria and bacteriuria. Also, pyelonephritis would not explain the patient's symptoms of polycythemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Hematuria is not a common symptom of renal oncocytoma and should raise suspicion of malignancy. In addition, this benign tumor does not cause paraneoplastic syndromes.

F) INCORRECT:

While large angiomyolipomas may present with hematuria, which is seen in this patient, they are most commonly asymptomatic. Angiomyolipomas do not typically cause paraneoplastic EPO or renin production.

G) CORRECT:

This patient has several risk factors (obesity, smoking, occupational exposure to gasoline) for renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Tumor invasion of the collecting system can cause hematuria, which is one of the most common manifestations in patients with symptomatic RCC. In addition, RCC can cause a number of paraneoplastic complications, including secondary polycythemia (due to ectopic EPO production) and hypertension (due to the release of renin). The classic triad of RCC (i.e., hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable mass) is only seen in 10–15% of patients; especially in obese patients, a renal abdominal mass may not be palpable.

Abdominal CT scan is the imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of RCC.
questions.hint: Hematuria in the absence of RBC casts on urinalysis indicates nonglomerular disease. The patient also presents with hypertension and features of polycythemia (headache, facial plethora, blurry vision), suggesting an increased production of renin and erythropoietin (EPO), respectively.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of blood in the urine and fatigue. He also has had a 5.0-kg (11-lb) weight loss during the past month. Physical examination shows pallor and cachexia. A nontender right flank mass is palpated. A CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows a 5-cm right upper pole renal mass and several pulmonary lesions. A biopsy specimen of an affected area of the lung is obtained. A photomicrograph of the biopsy specimen is shown. Molecular evaluation of the specimen is most likely to show which of the following genetic changes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

NF1 gene inactivation causes neurofibromatosis type 1. This condition classically manifests with café au lait spots, neurofibromas, and Lisch nodules, all of which are absent in this patient. Additionally, renal and pulmonary involvement is uncommon. Patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 have an increased risk of optic gliomas and pheochromocytoma, but not RCC.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

B) INCORRECT:

PKD1 gene mutations are the most common cause of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Typical disease manifestations include enlarged kidneys (due to extensive bilateral renal cysts), hepatic cysts, and chronic hypertension, which are absent in this patient. The incidence of RCC in patients with ADPKD does not appear to be increased compared with the general population.

C) CORRECT:

Deletions of the VHL tumor suppressor gene are a common cause of both sporadic and familial renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Most cases of RCC are sporadic, although a small percentage are associated with VHL gene deletions in hereditary disorders such as von Hippel-Lindau disease. Histologic examination of tissue shows polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm due to the accumulation of lipids and carbohydrates (clear cells). Gross specimens often appear yellow as a result of high lipid content.

For diagnosis of localized RCC, total/partial nephrectomy is preferred over tissue biopsy, as it allows the diagnosis to be definitively established and is an effective treatment option that minimizes the risk of bleeding and tumor seeding. In patients with suspected metastases, a biopsy of the (suspicious) metastatic lesion is necessary for establishing the diagnosis and confirming the stage of cancer.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (with oral and IV contrast; coronal plane) of patient with a history of renal cell carcinoma

A large mass with peripheral enhancement (blue overlay) and central necrosis (yellow overlay) arises from the mid pole of the right kidney. Soft tissue density (red overlay) visible in the perinephric space raises concern for extracapsular extension. A large pleural effusion (outline) accompanied by passive atelectasis (green overlay) depresses the right hemidiaphragm.

A : calcified abdominal aorta; C: colon; K: left kidney; L: liver

D) INCORRECT:

MYCL1 gene amplification is implicated in the pathogenesis of lung cancer (especially small cell lung cancer). This patient's signs, symptoms, and histologic findings suggest a diagnosis of clear cell RCC. The presence of multiple pulmonary lesions on CT scan represents metastatic disease, not primary lung disease. Also, MYCL1 amplification does not play a role in the pathogenesis of RCC.

E) INCORRECT:

TSC1 gene insertions cause tuberous sclerosis (TSC), which commonly manifests with renal angiomyolipomas and can affect the lungs. However, TSC causes diffuse, interstitial pulmonary fibrosis, not discrete lesions. Additionally, TSC typically also manifest with intellectual disability, epilepsy, and skin findings such as ash-leaf spots, shagreen patches, or angiofibromas which are not seen in this patient. Less than 5% of patients with TSC develop RCC.

F) INCORRECT:

WT1 gene deletion is associated with the development of nephroblastoma (i.e., Wilms tumor), which can present with a palpable, unilateral flank mass, hematuria, and pulmonary metastases, as seen in this patient. However, histologic examination of nephroblastoma typically shows embryonic glomerular structure, not clear cells. Additionally, this tumor rarely occurs in the adult population.
questions.hint: Fatigue, hematuria, weight loss, and a palpable renal mass are highly suggestive of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The lung is a common site of metastasis.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue and constipation. He reports having dull pain in the left portion of the midback for 2 weeks that has persisted despite taking ibuprofen. His father died of prostate cancer at 70 years of age. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a left-sided varicocele both in supine and in standing position. Rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged prostate with no masses. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.2 g/dL


Serum



 Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


 Calcium

11.8 mg/dL


Urine



 Protein
1+


 Blood

2+


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is highly suspicious of renal cell carcinoma (RCC): chronic fatigue, unilateral flank pain, hypercalcemia (secondary to paraneoplastic production of parathyroid-related protein), microscopic hematuria, and a left-sided varicocele that fails to resolve on lying down. Abdominal CT scan with contrast is the imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of RCC to demonstrate the extent of the lesion, and help determine if hilar lymph nodes and/or the renal vein are involved.

The classical triad of RCC consists of hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable flank mass. However, only 5–10% of patients present with all three components of the triad, and > 25% present with one or more atypical symptoms related to paraneoplastic syndromes and/or disseminated disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Scrotal ultrasound is the imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of varicocele (although it is often a clinical diagnosis). While this patient's physical examination shows varicocele, his other findings (left-sided flank pain, hypercalcemia, and hematuria), should raise concern for another ongoing pathology that warrants a different step.

C) INCORRECT:

Urine cytology can be used in the diagnosis of transitional cell carcinoma (TCC). The most common presentation of TCC is painless gross hematuria. Although this patient presents with hematuria, it is not painless. In addition, TCC does not cause varicocele, and hypercalcemia is uncommon. Moreover, urine cytology has low sensitivity (high false-negative rates) and is not routinely recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

Chest x-ray can be used as an initial investigation for patients with suspected lung cancer. Squamous cell lung carcinoma presents with fatigue, weight loss, and a smoking history, and can cause paraneoplastic hypercalcemia due to PTHrP production, which is consistent with this patient's history. However, lung cancer would not explain hematuria and varicocele, and other symptoms, such as hemoptysis and cough would be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Prostate biopsy is used to confirm prostatic carcinoma after a suspicious digital rectal examination (DRE) and/or elevated PSA levels. Prostatic carcinoma can present with hematuria and back pain when metastasized. However, this patient's DRE findings of symmetrically enlarged prostate with no masses is most likely due to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Moreover, prostatic carcinoma would not explain this patient's varicocele.

F) INCORRECT:

Serum protein electrophoresis is the best initial investigation for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. This condition can manifest with bone pain (especially back pain), symptoms of hypercalcemia, fatigue, and anemia. However, multiple myeloma does not cause hematuria or a varicocele.
questions.hint: Left-sided varicoceles that do not resolve in supine position should raise suspicion for a tumor that obstructs the inferior vena cava or left renal vein.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician with a 3-month history of right flank pain. Urinalysis shows 60 RBC/hpf. Renal ultrasound shows a 3 cm, well-defined mass in the upper pole of the right kidney with a central stellate scar. A photomicrograph of a section of the resected mass is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clear cell renal carcinoma is the most common histological variant of renal cell carcinoma (∼ 80% of all cases). On histology, these cells show clear cytoplasm under staining due to glycogen- or lipid-filled cytoplasm, which differs from this specimen.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Countless nests of polygonal cells (examples indicated by green overlays) with clear cytoplasm, filled with lipids and glycogen, are visible (examples indicated by yellow overlays). The tissue is richly vascularized (examples of blood vessels indicated by arrowheads).

This is the typical histopathological appearance of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Transitional cell carcinoma, while more typically a tumor of the bladder, can originate in the renal calyces or renal pelvis and cause flank pain and hematuria. However, the histological examination would show multiple frondlike papillary projections with dysplastic urothelium, which are not the findings in this specimen.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of bladder tissue (H&E stain, 75x magnification)

Green overlay: deepest invasive tumor front
Black arrow: urothelium
White arrow: bladder muscularis of bladder

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) CORRECT:

An oncocytoma is the most likely diagnosis in this patient who presents with symptoms of a renal tumor (painless hematuria, flank pain) and evidence of oncocytes on histopathology. Macroscopically, oncocytomas appear as well-circumscribed tumors with a central stellate scar, which is often visible on imaging. Oncocytomas are usually completely resected to definitively exclude the possibility of malignancy.
Image Description:

Gross pathology specimen of a kidney (sagittal section)

A well-circumscribed, mahogany-brown tumor (green overlay) with a central scar (hatched green overlay) is visible.

These findings are characteristic of a renal oncocytoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Nephroblastoma (i.e., Wilms tumor) consists of embryonic glomerular structures and may include cysts, hemorrhage, or necrosis. It also typically has a pseudocapsule. Additionally, this is a malignancy that presents almost exclusively in children.
Image Description:

MRI abdomen (T2-weighted with fat saturation; coronal plane) of a 3-year-old child

A large heterogeneous but relatively well-circumscribed solid mass is centered within the lower pole of the left kidney. Normal renal tissue is seen cranial to the mass. The hypointense areas of the mass suggest soft tissue, whereas the areas of hyperintensity suggest hemorrhage or necrosis.

Biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor), the most common type of pediatric renal cancer, with a peak incidence at 3–4 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma is identified on histology by large, polygonal cells with a prominent cell membrane, similar to the sample from this patient. However, chromophobe renal cell carcinoma is differentiated by the presence of perinuclear halos, which are absent here.

F) INCORRECT:

Angiomyolipoma would present on histology with abnormal blood vessels with thickened walls, spindle smooth muscle-like cells, and adipose tissue, none of which are seen in this specimen. Angiomyolipoma can present sporadically as solitary, unilateral tumors, or as part of a diagnosis of tuberous sclerosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Numerous mature adipocytes are visible, identifiable as large clear cells with a thin layer of eosinophilic cytoplasm and a peripherally placed basophilic nucleus (examples indicated by black arrowheads). Thick-walled blood vessels (green overlay) are scattered among the adipocytes. Bundles of transversely cut and longitudinally cut smooth muscle cells (red overlay) are visible on the right, and renal tubular architecture is visible on the extreme right.

The presence of mature adipocytes, blood vessels, and smooth muscle cells within the renal parenchyma is characteristic of renal angiomyolipoma.
questions.hint: This man’s biopsy shows large polygonal cells with eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm without perinuclear clearing.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with right-sided renal cell carcinoma comes to the physician because of shortness of breath for 1 month. Yesterday he had an episode of hemoptysis. He appears cachectic and chronically ill. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds throughout both lung fields. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen shows multiple pulmonary nodules. A CT scan of the abdomen is shown. This patient's tumor most likely spread via which of the following labeled structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Option A on this axial CT scan corresponds to the small intestine. Small intestinal metastasis from renal cell carcinoma is rare and the small intestine itself is not part of a route for hematogenous or lymphatogenous spread of metastatic RCC cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Option B on this axial CT scan corresponds to the mesenteric vessels. Although these vessels supply blood to and from the small intestine and large intestine, they do not supply the kidney. While metastatic RCC cells may eventually spread to the intestine via these vessels, they would first follow the path of venous and lymphatic drainage from the kidney.

C) INCORRECT:

Option C on this axial CT scan corresponds to the left-sided renal vessels. Although a left-sided tumor could metastasize hematogenously via the left renal vein, this patient has a right-sided RCC, which would follow a different path.

D) INCORRECT:

Option D on this axial CT scan corresponds to the aorta. Although hematogenously metastasizing RCC cells may eventually reach the arterial system, they first follow the path of venous drainage.

E) CORRECT:

Option E on this axial CT scan corresponds to the inferior vena cava (IVC). Venous drainage from the right kidney enters the right renal vein and flows into the IVC. By this route metastatic renal cell carcinoma (RCC) cells could be transported via the IVC to the right heart and from there into the lungs, causing this patient's pulmonary symptoms and pulmonary nodules on CT.
questions.hint: Renal cell carcinoma metastasizes via hematogenous and lymphatogenous spread. Hematogenous spread is usually via the venous system.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of several episodes of dark urine over the past 2 months. He has had a 6 kg (13.2-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months despite no changes in appetite. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. A CT scan shows a heterogeneous enhancing mass arising from the left renal pelvis. Pathologic examination of the lesion is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Pedunculated tumor comprised of pleomorphic urothelial cells with severe nuclear atypia
Grayish-brown tumor comprised of squamous cells with keratin pearls
Tumor with central scar comprised of large eosinophilic cells with central nuclei
Bright yellow tumor comprised of polygonal cells filled with lipids and glycogen
Grayish-tan tumor comprised of primitive blastemal cells forming abortive glomeruli

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

More than 90% of tumors arising from the renal pelvis and ureter are urothelial carcinomas. They typically manifest with either gross or microscopic hematuria (75% of cases), while flank pain only sometimes occurs (20% of cases). Less often, a lumbar mass or recurrent urinary tract infections are seen. The urinary collecting system is derived from the same embryologic origin (the ureteric bud), and, as a result, urothelial carcinomas appear identical to tumors arising from the bladder, with a papillary surface, large pleomorphic urothelial cells, and severe nuclear atypia. Tumors are often pedunculated.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of urothelial tissue (H&E stain; 750x magnification)

Papillary urothelial carcinoma with lamina propria infiltration, moderately differentiated.

A) Mitotic figure
B) Urothelial cell with severe nuclear atypia; no mitotic figure
C) Small, round lymphocytes; no mitotic figure
D) Structure with a nucleus
E) Atypical urothelial cell; no mitotic figure

B) INCORRECT:

Primary squamous cell cancer (SCC) of the renal pelvis accounts for less than 10% of all renal pelvic cancers. They are sometimes seen in association with chronic calculi or chronic infections. SCC is an aggressive tumor, often locally invasive at the time of diagnosis. Unlike the tumor in this patient, they tend to be sessile and not pedunculated. When present, they appear as grayish-brown tumors comprised of squamous cells with keratin pearls.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal oncocytomas are benign tumors that arise from the collecting ducts, not from the renal pelvis. They are usually incidental findings and are rarely symptomatic, unless they grow to be very large in size, at which point they can manifest with hematuria and/or flank pain, neither of which is present here. Pathologic examination of the tumor would reveal a central scar comprised of large eosinophilic cells with central nuclei and numerous mitochondria, without dysplastic urothelial cells.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinomas are bright yellow tumors comprised of polygonal clear cells filled with lipids and glycogen. They arise from the renal parenchyma, more specifically from the proximal convoluted tubule. Tumors of the renal pelvis are of urothelial origin.

E) INCORRECT:

Nephroblastoma, the most common renal tumor in children, has a grayish-tan appearance and is comprised of primitive blastemal cells that form abortive glomeruli. It usually manifests as a large abdominal mass and is sometimes associated with hematuria and abdominal pain, neither of which is the case here. Moreover, it is not seen in adults, making it extremely unlikely in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's renal pelvic mass has arisen from cells that derive from the caudal end of the mesonephric duct during embryologic development.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman reports a 2-month history of progressive leg swelling, mild intermittent abdominal discomfort, fatigue, 3.2 kg of unintended weight loss, and occasional visible hematuria. She reports no chest pain or dyspnea.
Her vital signs and cardiopulmonary examination are within normal limits, and her jugular venous pressure is not elevated. Her abdomen is not distended, and no masses are palpable. She has mild right-sided mid-abdominal tenderness to palpation, without rebound or guarding. Her extremities are notable for 2+ edema up to the hips, and her peripheral pulses are intact.
A urine dipstick is negative for proteinuria but 1+ positive for blood. The urine sediment shows 10 to 15 red cells per high-power field.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian cancer should be considered in any woman with abdominal discomfort and weight loss. However, bloating and increasing abdominal size (and not leg edema) are more likely to be dominant presenting findings, and the visible and microscopic hematuria suggest renal cancer rather than ovarian cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin A nephropathy often manifests with hematuria (either visible or microscopic) and mild proteinuria. Occasionally, nephrotic-range proteinuria with edema occurs in immunoglobulin A nephropathy, but proteinuria is absent in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s hematuria, weight loss, fatigue, and abdominal tenderness raise suspicion for malignancy, specifically renal-cell carcinoma. Renal-cell carcinoma has a predilection for vascular invasion. Venous tumor thrombus extending into the renal vein or inferior vena cava (IVC) occurs in up to 10% of affected patients and into the right atrium in up to 1% of affected patients. Significant obstruction of IVC blood flow can cause lower-extremity edema and varicosities.

Key learning point: The findings of hematuria with weight loss and lower-extremity swelling are most typical of a diagnosis of inferior vena cava obstruction that is associated with renal-cell carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal amyloidosis commonly causes nephrotic-range proteinuria but not hematuria.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal-vein thrombosis can be associated with nephrotic syndrome; it would not manifest with edema in the absence of proteinuria.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man recently received a diagnosis of metastatic renal-cell cancer. Treatment with sunitinib is planned.
Which one of the following measurements is appropriate as this patient begins his treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prolactin levels are rarely affected by sunitinib or other anticancer agents.

B) CORRECT:

In patients treated with sunitinib (a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat renal-cell cancer, gastrointestinal stromal tumors, and other cancers), the incidence of new-onset hypothyroidism is 32% to 85%. The most likely mechanism is thyroid capillary regression induced by sunitinib, leading to involution of the gland. In certain cases, this process may be sufficiently rapid to cause an initial thyrotoxic phase as a result of the uncontrolled release of thyroid hormone from the damaged thyroid gland.

Because symptoms of hypothyroidism can mimic symptoms of cancer progression and medication side effects, patients with such symptoms should undergo measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone. Screening is generally recommended before treatment is initiated and every 1 to 3 months thereafter.

Key learning point: The main endocrine side effect of sunitinib is hypothyroidism.

C) INCORRECT:

A morning cortisol level is not needed, because adrenal insufficiency does not seem to occur with sunitinib. It would be appropriate in a patient receiving treatment with ipilimumab or other agents that cause central adrenal insufficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of glycated hemoglobin is not needed, because sunitinib has minimal effects on glucose control. Such measurement would be appropriate in a patient receiving glucocorticoids.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of plasma renin activity is not needed. Although hypertension is a recognized side effect of sunitinib, the contribution from the renin-aldosterone-angiotensin system is unknown.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of hematuria. She denies any dysuria or urinary frequency but reports intermittent fevers and fatigue for the past month.
She has a brother who was diagnosed with an abdominal tumor that caused hypertension 6 months ago at the age of 37 and what she calls an “eye tumor” when he was young. She did not know her father but was told he died of an unknown cancer in his late 40s. Her urinalysis is positive for blood but otherwise negative.
Which one of the following evaluations is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy is appropriate when a lower urinary-tract cancer is suspected.

B) INCORRECT:

Urine culture is not helpful in patients with hematuria unless there are other clinical or urinalysis findings suggesting infection.

C) CORRECT:

Von Hippel-Lindau disease is a rare, autosomal dominant familial cancer syndrome consisting chiefly of retinal angioma, hemangioblastoma of the central nervous system, pheochromocytoma, and clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma. Among patients with von Hippel-Lindau disease, the mean age at diagnosis of renal-cell carcinoma is approximately 44 years, which is significantly older than the mean age at diagnosis of cerebellar hemangioblastoma and retinal angioma.

A patient who has a family history suggesting Von Hippel-Lindau and who presents with hematuria should have cross-sectional imaging of the kidneys. An enhancing renal mass on CT would be indicative of the presence of renal-cell carcinoma. Renal-cell carcinoma can manifest as hematuria, flank pain, or a palpable abdominal mass. Patients may also present with nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, or anemia.

Key learning point: The most appropriate imaging study to perform in a patient suspected of having renal-cell carcinoma is CT of the abdomen and pelvis.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound is not as sensitive or as specific as CT, which allows for the assessment of local invasiveness, lymph-node involvement, and other metastases.

E) INCORRECT:

Routine urine cytology is costly and of very limited clinical value as a first-line investigation for patients with hematuria.

questions.text:
An obese 63-year-old man comes to the office because of 3 episodes of red urine over the past week. During the past month, he has also had recurrent headaches and intermittent blurry vision. He works as an attendant at a gas station. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 152/95 mm Hg. Examination shows a flushed face. Urinalysis shows:


Blood
3+


Glucose
negative


Protein
negative


RBCs
40–45/hpf


RBC casts
none


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nephrolithiasis may present with hematuria, as described here. Small kidney stones may also be asymptomatic. However, the diagnosis is unlikely in a patient with gross hematuria but no symptoms of renal colic (e.g., severe unilateral and colicky flank pain). Nephrolithiasis would also not explain the patient's paraneoplastic EPO production.

B) INCORRECT:

Episodic gross hematuria may be seen in patients with IgA nephropathy. This condition commonly occurs in children and young adults with an upper respiratory infection or gastroenteritis, but this older patient did not report or show any signs of recent infection. Moreover, urinalysis in IgA nephropathy usually shows red blood cell casts (due to glomerular involvement), making the diagnosis even less likely in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Hematuria is not a common symptom of renal oncocytoma and should raise suspicion of malignancy. In addition, this benign tumor does not cause paraneoplastic syndromes.

D) INCORRECT:

While large angiomyolipomas may present with hematuria, which is seen in this patient, they are most commonly asymptomatic. Angiomyolipomas do not typically cause paraneoplastic EPO or renin production.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has several risk factors (obesity, smoking, occupational exposure to gasoline) for renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Tumor invasion of the collecting system can cause hematuria, which is one of the most common manifestations in patients with symptomatic RCC. In addition, RCC can cause a number of paraneoplastic complications, including secondary polycythemia (due to ectopic EPO production) and hypertension (due to the release of renin). The classic triad of RCC (i.e., hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable mass) is only seen in 10–15% of patients; especially in obese patients, a renal abdominal mass may not be palpable.

Abdominal CT scan is the imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of RCC.

Key learning point: Renal cell carcinoma often presents with painless hematuria and may cause paraneoplastic syndromes such as polycythemia and hypertension due to ectopic erythropoietin and renin production.
questions.hint: Hematuria in the absence of RBC casts on urinalysis indicates nonglomerular disease. The patient also presents with hypertension and features of polycythemia (headache, facial plethora, blurry vision), suggesting an increased production of renin and erythropoietin (EPO), respectively.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-month history of fatigue and constipation. He reports having dull pain in the left portion of the midback for 2 weeks that has persisted despite taking ibuprofen. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Physical examination shows a left-sided varicocele both in supine and in standing position. Rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged prostate with no masses. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.2 g/dL


Serum



 Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


 Calcium

11.8 mg/dL


Urine



 Protein
1+


 Blood

2+


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is highly suspicious of renal cell carcinoma (RCC): chronic fatigue, unilateral flank pain, hypercalcemia (secondary to paraneoplastic production of parathyroid-related protein), microscopic hematuria, and a left-sided varicocele that fails to resolve on lying down. Abdominal CT scan with contrast is the imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of RCC to demonstrate the extent of the lesion, and help determine if hilar lymph nodes and/or the renal vein are involved.

The classical triad of RCC consists of hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable flank mass. However, only 5–10% of patients present with all three components of the triad, and > 25% present with one or more atypical symptoms related to paraneoplastic syndromes and/or disseminated disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Scrotal ultrasound is the imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of varicocele (although it is often a clinical diagnosis). While this patient's physical examination shows varicocele, his other findings (left-sided flank pain, hypercalcemia, and hematuria), should raise concern for another ongoing pathology that warrants a different step.

C) INCORRECT:

Urine cytology can be used in the diagnosis of transitional cell carcinoma (TCC). The most common presentation of TCC is painless gross hematuria. Although this patient presents with hematuria, it is not painless. In addition, TCC does not cause varicocele, and hypercalcemia is uncommon. Moreover, urine cytology has low sensitivity (high false-negative rates) and is not routinely recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

Prostate biopsy is used to confirm prostatic carcinoma after a suspicious digital rectal examination (DRE) and/or elevated PSA levels. Prostatic carcinoma can present with hematuria and back pain when metastasized. However, this patient's DRE findings of symmetrically enlarged prostate with no masses is most likely due to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Moreover, prostatic carcinoma would not explain this patient's varicocele.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum protein electrophoresis is the best initial investigation for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. This condition can manifest with bone pain (especially back pain), symptoms of hypercalcemia, fatigue, and anemia. However, multiple myeloma does not cause hematuria or a varicocele.
questions.hint: Left-sided varicoceles that do not resolve in supine position should raise suspicion for a tumor that obstructs the inferior vena cava or left renal vein.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents with right flank pain and intermittent pink-tinged urine for the past three weeks. He is otherwise healthy. Vital signs are stable. Physical examination reveals no costovertebral angle tenderness. Serum creatinine is normal (see report).
Renal ultrasound: 3-cm heterogeneous lesion in the right kidney; lacks clear delineation of the lesion’s characteristics
Which of the following is the most appropriate imaging study to further evaluate this suspected renal mass?

choices.text: MRI of the abdomen without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelogram (IVP) provides two-dimensional images that inadequately characterize renal mass architecture and enhancement patterns. It lacks the detailed anatomic resolution and contrast differentiation offered by modern imaging modalities, making it suboptimal for assessing suspected renal malignancies.

B) INCORRECT:

Noncontrast CT cannot evaluate enhancement patterns within a renal lesion, which are crucial for distinguishing benign from malignant etiologies. While it provides basic anatomic information, it lacks the multiphasic evaluation needed to identify features like arterial hypervascularity, limiting its diagnostic utility in this context.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI without contrast avoids ionizing radiation but lacks the ability to discern vascularity and internal architecture of renal masses. Contrast enhancement is essential for differentiating benign from malignant processes. Without contrast, MRI cannot adequately assess lesion margins or detect subtle enhancement patterns.

D) CORRECT:

Contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen is the preferred imaging modality for evaluating a suspected renal mass due to its high spatial resolution and ability to assess enhancement patterns. Intravenous contrast in a multiphasic protocol highlights vascularity, structure, and potential local invasion, differentiating between neoplastic and benign features. This detailed visualization is crucial when prior imaging, such as renal ultrasound, provides ambiguous findings. Enhanced imaging also facilitates staging by identifying extension into adjacent tissues and renal vasculature involvement.

Key learning point: For suspected renal masses, a CT scan is the most diagnostic imaging modality, providing detailed information about the mass and its characteristics.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (with oral and IV contrast; axial plane) of a patient with history of renal cell carcinoma

A large mass with peripheral enhancement (blue overlay) and central necrosis (yellow overlay) arises from the mid pole of the right kidney. Soft tissue density (red overlay) visible in the perinephric space raises concern for extracapsular extension.

A: calcified abdominal aorta; C: colon; K: left kidney, L: liver

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man with obesity comes to your clinic because he has had 3 episodes of red urine over the past week. Over the past month, he has also experienced recurrent headaches and intermittent blurry vision. He works as a gas station attendant and has a 40-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. His temperature is 37.4°C, pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 152/95 mm Hg. On examination, his face appears flushed. Urinalysis shows the following:


Blood, urine
3+


Glucose, urine
Negative


Protein, urine
Negative


RBCs, urine
40–45/hpf


RBC casts, urine
None


Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hematuria is not a common symptom of renal oncocytoma and should raise suspicion of malignancy. In addition, this benign tumor does not cause paraneoplastic syndromes.

B) INCORRECT:

Nephrolithiasis may present with hematuria, as described here. Small kidney stones may also be asymptomatic. However, the diagnosis is unlikely in a patient with gross hematuria but no symptoms of renal colic (e.g., severe unilateral and colicky flank pain). Nephrolithiasis would also not explain the patient's paraneoplastic EPO production.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has several risk factors (obesity, smoking, occupational exposure to gasoline) for renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Tumor invasion of the collecting system can cause hematuria, which is one of the most common manifestations in patients with symptomatic RCC. In addition, RCC can cause a number of paraneoplastic complications, including secondary polycythemia (due to ectopic EPO production) and hypertension (due to the release of renin). The classic triad of RCC (i.e., hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable mass) is only seen in 10–15% of patients; especially in obese patients, a renal abdominal mass may not be palpable.

Abdominal CT scan is the imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of RCC.

Key learning point: Renal cell carcinoma often presents with hematuria and paraneoplastic syndromes such as hypertension and polycythemia, especially in patients with risk factors like smoking and obesity.

D) INCORRECT:

Episodic gross hematuria may be seen in patients with IgA nephropathy. This condition commonly occurs in children and young adults with an upper respiratory infection or gastroenteritis, but this older patient did not report or show any signs of recent infection. Moreover, urinalysis in IgA nephropathy usually shows red blood cell casts (due to glomerular involvement), making the diagnosis even less likely in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

While large angiomyolipomas may present with hematuria, which is seen in this patient, they are most commonly asymptomatic. Angiomyolipomas do not typically cause paraneoplastic EPO or renin production.
questions.hint: Hematuria in the absence of RBC casts on urinalysis indicates nonglomerular disease. The patient also presents with hypertension and features of polycythemia (headache, facial plethora, blurry vision), suggesting an increased production of renin and erythropoietin (EPO), respectively.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man with a history of renal cell carcinoma presents to the emergency department with progressive lethargy, nausea, and generalized weakness for four days. He denies headache, abdominal pain, or urinary symptoms. Vital signs are BP, 128/74 mm Hg; P, 68; R, 14; T, 36.7°C (98.1°F). Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes, slowed speech, and mild confusion without focal neurologic deficits. No laboratory results are yet available. Which paraneoplastic process most likely explains this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Ectopic ACTH secretion causing Cushing syndrome
Parathyroid hormone–related peptide (PTHrP) secretion causing hypercalcemia

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythropoietin excess from RCC causes headache, hypertension, and ruddy complexion due to increased red cell mass. It does not lead to dehydration, confusion, or lethargy, which are hallmarks of hypercalcemia.

B) INCORRECT:

SIADH causes hyponatremia with symptoms of nausea, confusion, and seizures but typically presents with euvolemia and moist mucous membranes. This patient’s dry mucosa and dehydration are inconsistent with SIADH. Additionally, SIADH is not typically associated with renal cell carcinoma and occurs more frequently as a paraneoplastic manifestation of other malignancies, particularly small cell lung carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Cushing syndrome from ectopic ACTH production produces hyperglycemia, muscle weakness, and truncal obesity over time. It does not cause acute dehydration or confusion as seen with hypercalcemia.

D) CORRECT:

Correct — Ectopic PTHrP secretion is a well-recognized paraneoplastic manifestation of renal cell carcinoma. It increases bone resorption and renal calcium reabsorption, leading to hypercalcemia. The resulting dehydration, lethargy, and altered mental status often prompt emergency evaluation before the diagnosis is confirmed by laboratory testing.

E) INCORRECT:

Limbic encephalitis is a rare autoimmune paraneoplastic syndrome that presents with memory loss, seizures, and personality change rather than dehydration or the generalized weakness seen here. The subacute course and systemic signs in this patient favor a metabolic process.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-month history of intermittent, painless gross hematuria and a 4.5 kg (10 lb) unintentional weight loss. He has persistent dull left-sided flank pain. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg. Physical examination shows a firm, non-tender mass in the left upper quadrant. Additionally, a left-sided varicocele is noted, which does not decompress when the patient is in the supine position. Laboratory studies reveal a hematocrit of 55% and a serum calcium of 11.2 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation of flank pain, hematuria, and a palpable abdominal mass, along with constitutional symptoms like weight loss, raises suspicion for renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The left-sided varicocele that fails to decompress when supine, suggesting obstruction of the left gonadal vein, likely from tumor thrombus extension in the left renal vein, is a specific physical examination finding consistent with RCC. Additionally, erythrocytosis due to ectopic erythropoietin production, hypercalcemia from parathyroid hormone-related peptide secretion, and hypertension suggest paraneoplastic syndromes. Smoking is a major risk factor for RCC.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyelonephritis is an infection of the kidney that presents with flank pain and can cause hematuria. However, it is an acute infectious process typically accompanied by fever, chills, and costovertebral angle tenderness, not a chronic course with a palpable mass and weight loss. Laboratory findings would show leukocytosis and pyuria, not erythrocytosis or hypercalcemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Urothelial carcinoma is associated with smoking and commonly presents with painless gross hematuria. However, it typically arises from the renal pelvis or bladder lining, making a large palpable parenchymal mass less common. Furthermore, the paraneoplastic syndromes of erythrocytosis and hypercalcemia are associated with a different condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease can present with palpable flank masses, flank pain, hematuria, and hypertension. However, it is a chronic genetic condition, and the subacute onset with significant weight loss is atypical. It is associated with progressive renal failure and anemia due to decreased erythropoietin production, not erythrocytosis or hypercalcemia.

E) INCORRECT:

An angiomyolipoma is a benign renal tumor that can cause a palpable mass, flank pain, and hematuria if it ruptures. However, it does not cause constitutional symptoms like weight loss, nor does it produce paraneoplastic syndromes such as erythrocytosis and hypercalcemia.
